comments.commentBody:
The other very helpful (and empathetic) observation came from Chris Evert, when she explained how overwhelmed she was by the occasion of her first Wimbledon final -- when she lost, 6-0, 6-4. And this from a player known for her ability to control her nerves! Lisicki's greatest liability is the susceptibility of her game to her mood of the moment; I hope this final will be a catalyst to helping her learn to control her nerves better, and thus to capitalize on her innate athletic gifts.

Brava to Bartoli for harnessing her gifts so well to the moment. It must not be easy to shut out the distractions of that 175-IQ brain and let her tennis flow.
Nothing makes me disrespect the Firearms Cult more than its insistent demands for internet citations to confirm the obvious.
I haven't read a gun advocate here yet who impresses me as trustworthy with deadly weapons.
Screw Texas, I have no need ever to go there again.

The key thing you're missing is that you don't have to look at trying to make first class revenue equal coach revenue, you have to look at revenue per seat, and what they could be doing with that space otherwise.

So, for example, in the plane you cite, it's a 4 seat x 4 row configuration in first class, vs 6 seats in coach per row. Take into account the extra legroom, and roughly 16 seats in First compare to probably 36 seats in coach (that is, if you took out first class and replaced it with coach, you could fit an extra 36 seats in, roughly).

I picked an example flight leaving next thursday from Newark to San Francisco. A coach ticket one-way is $468, the same flight first class is $1,552.

$468 * 36 = $16,848
$1,552 * 16 = $24,832

First class seats make $8k more on that flight than the same amount of coach seats would have. Divide that out by 144 seats in the rest of the plane, and that's a $55 subsidy that first class is providing *per coach passenger* to the rest of the plane

Still, the bulk of the flight is being paid for by the majority of the people riding. They may be paying less because of the presence of first class passengers, but no one would be going anywhere without the coach section. I remember a time when there would be several seats empty on flight. Now that almost never happens because of the emphasis airlines put on filling each flight to capacity. They need all seats filled, not just the ones paying a premium.

With precious few travel alternatives in this country, the airline monopolies have passengers over the proverbial barrel. If you can't pay $1300 to go to San Francisco from Newark, it's tuck in your legs or drive.
Another point for business travel which is often last minute the fares can be much higher than the $4500 you figured.

Some seem to think that the expense of first class tickets make it possible for many more of us to have a reduced price on economy seating; that in effect, the first class patrons are subsidizing the less expensive economy class. I'm not so sure.

Based on viewing a seat map of a United Boeing 737 passenger airplane, there are listed 16 first class seats and 144 economy seats, nine times as many economy seats as in first class. For the sake of argument, let's try a hypothetical round-trip flight from A to B. If each economy seat is $500, and the section is sold out, the airline grosses $72,000.

For the first class section to bring in as much cash as the economy section, not counting all the perks they get with their seat, each first class seat would have to cost $4500 with every seat filled. How often does this happen? I doubt the airlines would be terribly forthcoming with their data, but really, I'd like to know, who is subsidizing whom?

@Texas Pete -- "The Photo depicts an anti tank gun. Becuase its bore is greater than .50 Caliber it is a Class III weapon, it is difficult to import into the country and illegal to do so for civillian use. "

And can we presume, based on your previous posts, that this and other elements of the NFA and SCOTUS decisions constitute infringement of your 2nd Amendment rights?

Or would you be filing suit if only you could afford the thing?
I needed no expert at all to tell me that the smartest move was to toss the gun into the lake. I have never had the slightest regret that I did it.

False! Terrible analysis! Seles never won Wimbledon bc the low ball forced her two handed drives to hit up with spin instead on driving a high bounce ball flat (like the French where she won three times). Monica's game, like Bartoli, is suited for clay with high bounces where they can drive the ball, not the dying bounce of grass where they are forced to hit looping balls up.

"She plays well on grass because the low bounce comes right into the wheelhouse of her Monica Seles-inspired two-handed ground strokes."

I'm thoroughly convinced that both the TSA and sobriety check points are anti-constitutional regardless of what the Supreme court has to say.  Why the US public has been so quick to give up civil rights in the name of so called safety is a mystery to me.  The fear mongers have done a wonderful job through the years I guess.

In most of the larger cities, you can pay $100 for Global Entry (rapid TSA processing for overseas travel), no where near 1% or elite territory, do a TSA interview and fingerprinting, and be "good to go" for five years, rapidly, at many larger airports. (You get TSA domestic "pre check" thrown in for free.) Now, your privacy is invaded, "big time", with behind the scenes checking of government databases. But whose isn't these days! Note: If you've been arrested in the last ten years, you MAY not qualify. There you go, welcome to "psuedo-elite"!

Kevin and tcaldwell, just so you understand, there's no government involvement with the priority lines for first class and "premier/elite" passengers.

The TSA sets up the checkpoints. The airports and the airlines work together to decide how the lanes are set up that lead up to the checkpoints. This is why even people in the priority line might end up waiting at the document screener while a family of 6 in the regular line has their documents checked. The TSA just takes the people as they get to the front of the queue

The other thing I'll say, as someone who was one of those priority passengers for years when I traveled for business - the vast majority of people who get to go in that priority line are not wealthy, they're people who travel for work, often in coach, and in exchange for their loyalty the airline gives them some meager perks, like not having to wait in the regular line.

And when you've been in 4 cities in 5 days, 8 flights, 6 of which were in middle seats, and you're rushing to catch yet another flight, shaving 10 minutes off of the security line might make the difference between getting home or not that night.

Money talks, that's the answer to most of these issues.  The one issue of concern to me, where money should not talk, is the ability of the wealthy to go more quickly through government-mandated security, i.e., the metals detectors and luggage scanners.  The long lines exist because we refuse to devote sufficient resurces such that there are no  lines.   How difficult would it be to add more machines and employees during the rush?  But we don't, and thus, the demand is created, and the ability for someone to make money by selling access to a shorter line.  They call those shorter lines different names, usually by some precious metal or exclusive membership status.  And the process of watching a man in expensive clothes fly past you through security looks and feels like the same honest capitaliism you face on the plane, where the rich board first and get free drinks for $1000 extra -- more power to 'em.   But express lanes on government security checkpoints are a completely different animal.   Imagine if people driving Cadillacs were ushered to the front of police drunk driving checkpoints.   That's essentially what we have with fast lanes through metal detectors.  I would prefer we simply purchased more detectors and employed more guards so there are no unreasonably long waits, but fast lanes for the wealthy through security checkpoints should be prohibited.

What a great analysis. Thank you. These athletes seem ultra-human to me at times in their abilities, both physical and mental. It's nice to know they can also have days just like us, vulnerable to nerves, insecurities, and self-consciousness. If I could only bottle the confidence Bartoli showed today during my own Interclub matches. Definitely something to think about for next time.

Come on, Bartoli does her antics as much to psych out her opponents as to concentrate. We all know that. It was at one time what would have been called bad sportsmanship, but now it's just the new normal. In reply to criticism, apologists also justified Sharapova's screaming as helping her concentrate and reflecting her intensity. Now, that It has been seen to give her an advantage, everyone is starting to do it. How long before men are all grunting and all doubles teams are imitating the annoying Mexican jumping bean act the Bryan brothers do. It all starts as psychological warfare that tests the limits of sportsmanship. But then it gets normalized. Go to junior tournaments. Even kids are imitating this behavior, grunting, jumping up and down when your opponent is serving, fist pumping, and yelling "come on! after an opponent hits it out. Sure, it eventually becomes second nature and "unconscious," and probably helps players concentrate as various rituals do, but it all starts out as bad sportsmanship. So please, don't argue it is admirable and necessary. The game could be, and was for decades, played just as well without all the allegedly necessary "eccentricities."

I'd say I wish we could go back to the days of Woodward and Bernstein, but even Woodward is a complete joke anymore. The politicians, hacks, hangers on mentioned in the story-their behavior highligted here is to be expected. But I had higher hopes for the journalists. I often wonder what they teach at Columbia Journalism school anymore. We have the most ill informed nation in the world, and the blame for that lays squarely on "The Fifth Estate" or whatever the media used to be called.
And everyone complaining about politics and politicians in Washington, this crisis could be solved simply, cheaply and simply. Have the news people get off this circus truck.
Like that will ever happen any more. That ship has sailed, that train has left the station, and we're all doomed.
Your country is misnamed.  "Nonsequituria" would be better.

I watched every point of that match and I was mesmerized. I cannot imagine hitting a running forehand cross court at 120MPH as Del Po did.

His forehand is huge. Tennis man....

You guys in Artillery outfits might think that,and it may even be true in some conventional infantry units,but not in SF. In SF you don't get a CIB unless you have personally been fired on and personally returned fire in a actual firefight. None of that "A mortar round landed on the other side of the firebase" crap.

I personally knew a man that had been fired on several times but still didn't get his CIB because he was on a recon team at the time and it was probing fire so he couldn't return the fire.
Mr. Everman, Thank you for your service to your country.  Enjoy this 4th of July, and keep safe.

Everman might be one of the coolest college professors ever, but not THE coolest. These faculty too were once pretty cool:

John A. Tichy, Professor and former Head of the Department of Mechanical Aerospace and Nuclear Engineering at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute was once the singer, songwriter and guitarist with Commander Cody and his Lost Planet Airmen who used to open for the Grateful Dead.

Robert Leonard, a professor of linguistics at Hofstra University was a founding member of Sha Na Na.

Alan Cooper, the lead singer for Sha Na Na at Woodstock is the Elaine Ravich Professor of Jewish Studies and provost at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America.

Frederick "Denny" Greene of Sha Na Na is a professor of law at the University of Dayton.

Bruce "Bruno" Clarke of Sha Na Na is a professor of English at Texas Tech University.
Desperation leads to many things.

How amazingly cool.
In the world of traditional values i live in, to be a soldier or a scholar are much higher than being an entertainer. Hats off to you, sir, twice!
What a great article! A life of selfless devotion and commitment to the things that make us humans. Everman is a character from an 19th century novel. Joseph Conrad’s Heart of Darkness comes to me.

What a great article, what an amazing life story. Really breaks my preconceived notions of what kind of person would be a rock musician. Maybe it is proof that the bad things in life are not being done to you, they are being done for you (to test you, to challenge you, to take you out of your comfortable chair). After all they don't temper steel by putting it in a feather bed.
Was there something in the article that implied that the writer assumed Mr. Everman isn't smart?

If the writer knew anything about the Army, about the Special Forces, and the language school (presumably the Defense Language Institute), he would have realized that this guy is at least pretty smart. If he attended the Defense Language Institute to learn Pashto, Arabic, or Farsi, that means that Jason Everman is blisteringly intelligent. You don't GET to attend DLI, much less survive the instruction, if you aren't scary smart.

Still, it's an interesting article about a very interesting guy.
I'm not sure that's what Neal Young had in mind!
Not every war the US has fought in has preserved Ameicans' liberties. Not lately!
Buddha didn't join the Special Forces!
